text.p: The Venezuelan bolivar softened to 472.75/473.75 per dollar in a day's trading that saw only modest Central Bank presence, traders said.
The unit closed Tuesday at 472.50/473.50 per dollar.
"The Central Bank intervened in the morning to cover dollar shortages," said one trader. "But its was hardly around in the afternoon."
With the local press circulating reports that a visiting IMF mission views the bolivar as over-valued one trader said: "perhaps the Central Bank is letting the bolivar soften."
Demand for dollars is traditionally strong ahead of Christmas leaving the Central Bank the main supplier of dollars to the market. The bolivar has softened 0.8 percent over the past two weeks.
